{{Infobox ancient site | name = Q'umarkaj | alternate_name = Utatlán | image = Utatlan1.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = The ruins of Q'umarkaj, with the [[Mesoamerican ballcourt|ballcourt]] at left and the temple of Tohil to the right.<ref name="Kelly 1996, p.201" /> | map = | map_type = Mesoamerica#Guatemala | map_alt = | map_caption = Location of the site | map_size = | relief = | coordinates = {{coord|15|1|24.7|N|91|10|19.16|W|display=inline,title}} | map_dot_label = | location = [[Santa Cruz del Quiché]], [[Quiché Department]], [[Guatemala]] | region = | type = Settlement | built = 1400 | abandoned = 1524 | epochs = Late Postclassic | cultures = [[Maya civilization]] | event = | excavations = | archaeologists = | condition = In ruins | architectural_styles = | architectural_details = | notes = | precolumbian = yes <!-- non-functional tracking parameter, do not remove/change --> }} '''Q'umarkaj''', ([[K'iche' language|K'iche']]: {{IPA|[qʔumarˈkah]}}) (sometimes rendered as '''Gumarkaaj''', '''Gumarcaj''', '''Cumarcaj''' or '''Kumarcaaj''') is an archaeological site in the southwest of the [[El Quiché]] department of [[Guatemala]].<ref name="Kelly 1996, p.200">Kelly 1996, p.200.</ref> Q'umarkaj is also known as '''Utatlán''', the [[Nahuatl language|Nahuatl]] translation of the city's name. The name comes from [[K'iche' language|K'iche']] ''Q'umarkah'' "Place of old reeds".<ref name="Kelly 1996, p.200" />
Q'umarkaj was one of the most powerful [[Maya civilization|Maya]] cities when the [[Spanish people|Spanish]] arrived in the region in the early 16th century.<ref>Sharer & Traxler 2006, p.4.</ref> It was the capital of the [[K'iche' people|K'iche' Maya]] in the [[Mesoamerican chronology|Late Postclassic]] Period.<ref>Sharer & Traxler 2006, pp.621-622.</ref> At the time of the [[Spanish conquest of Guatemala|Spanish Conquest]], Q'umarkaj was a relatively new capital, with the capital of the [[K'iche' Kingdom of Q'umarkaj|K'iche' kingdom]] having originally been situated at Jakawitz (identified with the archaeological site [[Chitinamit]]) and then at [[Q'umarkaj#Pismachi'|Pismachi']].<ref>Sharer & Traxler 2006, pp.622-623. Carmack 2001a, p.155.</ref> Q'umarkaj was founded during the reign of king Q'uq'umatz ("Feathered Serpent" in K'iche') in the early 15th century, immediately to the north of Pismachi'.<ref name="Sharer & Traxler 2006, p.623">Sharer & Traxler 2006, p.623.</ref> In 1470 the city was seriously weakened by a rebellion among the nobility that resulted in the loss of key allies of the K'iche'.
[[archaeology|Archaeologically]] and [[ethnohistory|ethnohistorically]], Q'umarkaj is the best known of the Late Postclassic [[Guatemalan Highlands|highland]] Maya capitals.<ref name="Coe 1999, p.189" /> The earliest reference to the site in [[Spanish language|Spanish]] occurs in [[Hernán Cortés]]' letters from [[Mexico]]. Although the site has been investigated, little reconstruction work has taken place. The surviving [[Maya architecture|architecture]], which includes a [[Mesoamerican ballcourt]], temples and palaces, has been badly damaged by the looting of stone to build the nearby town of [[Santa Cruz del Quiché]].
The major structures of Q'umarkaj were laid out around a plaza. They included the temple of [[Tohil]], a [[jaguar]] god who was patron of the city, the temple of [[Awilix]], the patron goddess of one of the noble houses, the temple of [[Jacawitz|Jakawitz]], a mountain deity who was also a noble patron and the temple of [[Q'uq'umatz]], the [[Feathered Serpent (deity)|Feathered Serpent]], the patron of the royal house. The main ballcourt was placed between the palaces of two of the principal noble houses. Palaces, or ''nimja'', were spread throughout the city. There was also a platform that was used for gladiatorial sacrifice.
The area of Greater Q'umarkaj was divided into four major political division, one for each of the most important ruling lineages, and also encompassed a number of smaller satellites sites, including Chisalin, Pismachi', Atalaya and Pakaman.<ref name="Carmack & Weeks 1981, p.326" /> The site core is open to the public and includes basic infrastructure, including a small site museum.<ref>Vásquez et al. 2009, p.3.</ref>
==Etymology== Q'umarkaj comes from the K'iche' ''Q'umqaraq'aj''.<ref name="Coe 1999, p.189" /> While often translated as "place of old reeds" or "place of rotted cane",<ref name="Sharer 2000, p.490">Sharer 2000, p.490.</ref> the name Q'uma'rka'aaj translates more precisely as "rotted reed houses" (q'uma'r = "rotten";<ref>Christenson.</ref> ka'aaj = "house or shack built of cane and reeds"). It was translated as ''Tecpan Utatlan'' by the Nahuatl-speaking [[Tlaxcala]]n allies of the Spanish [[conquistador]]s,<ref name="Sharer & Traxler 2006, pp.764-765">Sharer & Traxler 2006, pp.764-765.</ref> with ''Tecpan'' being added to distinguish the city as being a seat of rule, equivalent to the ''[[Tollan]]'' used in [[Mesoamerica]] in earlier times.<ref name="Fox 1989, p.667">Fox 1989, p.667.</ref>
==Location== The ruins of the city are {{convert|2.5|km|mi}} to the west of the modern city of [[Santa Cruz del Quiché]].<ref name= "Carmack 2001a, p.218">Carmack 2001a, p.218.</ref> Q'umarkaj completely occupies {{convert|120000|m2|sqft}} of an easily defended [[plateau]] surrounded by [[ravine]]s over {{convert|100|m|ft}} deep.<ref name="Sharer & Traxler 2006, p.623"/><ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.218" /> The ravines are part of a drainage system feeding the [[Negro River (Guatemala)|Negro River]], which flows into the [[Chixoy River]] and eventually into the [[Usumacinta River]] and the [[Gulf of Mexico]].<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.218" /> A natural causeway to the southeast of the site links the plateau with a wide plain to the east.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.218" />
Q'umarkaj is the largest in a group of five major sites tightly clustered in an area of {{convert|4|km2|sqmi}}, with the area between the sites showing signs of also having been heavily occupied.<ref name="Carmack & Weeks 1981, p.326">Carmack & Weeks 1981, p.326.</ref> [[Q'umarkaj#Atalaya|Atalaya]] and [[Q'umarkaj#Pakaman|Pakaman]] lie to the east, [[Q'umarkaj#Pismachi'|Pismachi']] lies to the south and [[Q'umarkaj#Chisalin|Chisalin]] is to the north.<ref name="Carmack & Weeks 1981, p.326" />
==Inhabitants== {{Maya civilization}} In the Late Postclassic, the greater Q'umarkaj area is estimated to have had a population of around 15,000.<ref>Fox 1989, p.673.n2.</ref> The inhabitants of Q'umarkaj were divided socially between the [[nobility]] and their [[vassal]]s.<ref name="Coe 1999, p.189" /> The nobles were known as the ''[[ajaw]]'', while the vassals were known as the ''[[al k'ajol]]''.<ref name="Sharer & Traxler 2006, p.717" /> The nobility were the [[Patrilineality|patrilineal]] descendents of the founding warlords who appear to have entered as conquerors from the [[Gulf Coast of Mexico|Gulf coast]] around AD 1200 and who eventually lost their original language and adopted that of their subjects.<ref name="Coe 1999, p.189" /><ref name="Sharer 2000, p.490"/> The nobles were regarded as sacred and bore royal imagery.<ref name ="Coe 1999, p.189">Coe 1999, p.189.</ref> Their vassals served as foot-soldiers and were subject to the laws laid out by the nobility, although they could receive military titles as a result of their battlefield prowess.<ref name="Coe 1999, p.189" /> The social divisions were deep seated and were equivalent to strictly observed [[caste]]s.<ref name="Coe 1999, p.189" /> The merchants were a privileged class, although they had to make tributary payments to the nobility.<ref name="Coe 1999, p.189" /> In addition to these classes, the population included rural labourers and artisans.<ref name="Coe 1999, p.189" /> Slaves were also held and included both sentenced criminals and prisoners of war.<ref name="Coe 1999, p.189" />
There were twenty-four important lineages, or ''nimja'',<ref name="Sharer & Traxler 2006, p.717" /> in Q'umarkaj, closely linked to the palaces in which the nobility attended to their duties;<ref name="Coe 1999, p.190" /> ''Nimja'' means "big house" in K'iche', after the palace complexes that the lineages occupied.<ref name="Carmack & Weeks 1981, p.329">Carmack & Weeks 1981, p.329.</ref> Their duties included marriage negotiations and associated feasting and ceremonial lecturing.<ref name="Coe 1999, p.190" /> These lineages were strongly patrilineal and were grouped into four larger, more powerful ''nimja''<ref name="Carmack & Weeks 1981, p.329"/> that chose the rulers of the city.<ref name="Sharer & Traxler 2006, p.717" /> At the time of the [[Spanish conquest of Guatemala|Conquest]], the four ruling ''nimja'' were the Kaweq, the Nijaib, the Saqik and the Ajaw K'iche'.<ref name="Sharer & Traxler 2006, p.717" /> The Kaweq and the Nijaib included nine principal lineages each, the Ajaw K'iche' included four and the Saqik had two.<ref name="Carmack & Weeks 1981, p.329"/> As well as choosing the king and king elect, the ruling Kaweq dynasty also had a lineage that produced the powerful priests of [[Gukumatz|Q'uq'umatz]], who may have served as stewards of the city.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.367"/>
The K'iche' kingdom was ruled by a king, a king-elect and two captains,<ref name="Coe 1999, p.190">Coe 1999, p.190.</ref> a four-way joint rule embodied in four leaders, one from each of the four most important lineages in the city of Q'umarkaj.<ref name="Coe 1999, p.190" /> This form of rule was also known among the Maya of [[Yucatan]].<ref name="Coe 1999, p.190" /> The ruling lineage was the Kaweq ("Rain") dynasty, that chose both the king and the king-elect.<ref>Coe 1999, p.190. Sharer & Traxler 2006, p.717.</ref> The king was known as the ''ajpop'', "He of the Mat".<ref name="Sharer & Traxler 2006, p.623"/> The king-elect bore the title of ''ajpop k'amha'' and assisted the king until he became king himself.<ref name="Sharer & Traxler 2006, p.717">Sharer & Traxler 2006, p.717.</ref> The Nijaib and the Saqik noble houses chose the ''q'alel'' (supreme judge) and the Ajaw K'iche' chose the ''atzij winaq'' (speaker).<ref name="Sharer & Traxler 2006, p.717" />
==History== {{main article|K'iche' Kingdom of Q'umarkaj}}
Ceramic remains from the site include pieces that date as far back as the [[Mesoamerican chronology|Preclassic Period]] but the majority of finds date to the Late Postclassic and the height of the K'iche' kingdom.<ref name="Kelly 1996, p.201">Kelly 1996, p.201.</ref>
===Founding and expansion=== {|class="wikitable" style="float:right;margin:.5em" border="1" ! Ruler's Name !! Ruled |- |Q'uq'umatz<ref name="Sharer & Traxler 2006, p.626">Sharer & Traxler 2006, p.626.</ref> |1400–1425 |- |K'iq'ab<ref name="Sharer & Traxler 2006, p.626" /> |1425–1475 |- |Vahxak' i-Kaam<ref name="Sharer & Traxler 2006, p.626" /> |1475–1500 |- |Oxib-Keh<ref name="Sharer & Traxler 2006, p.626" /> |1500–1524 |- |colspan="2"|''All dates are approximate.'' |} The site was founded by king Q'uq'umatz around 1400 for its defensive position,<ref name="Kelly 1996, p.201" /> however there is some disagreement as to whether he is a historical or a mythological figure.<ref name="Carmack 2001b, p.178">Carmack 2001b, p.178.</ref> Q'uq'umatz is K'iche for feathered serpent, and feathered serpent is used as a title in other parts of [[Mesoamerica]].<ref name="Carmack 2001b, p.178" /> It is probable that Q'uq'umatz was really the title of another ''ajpop'' mentioned in the sources, Kotuja', and was actually the same individual.<ref>Carmack 2001b, pp.180-1.</ref> In the ''Título de los Señores de Totonicapán'', an early Colonial era K'iche' document, he is listed as Q'uq'umatz Kotuja'.<ref name="Carmack 2001b, p.181">Carmack 2001b, p.181.</ref> In the same title, his father is listed as Kotuja' Q'uq'umatz, and there is confusion in the K'iche' documents as to whether they were one and the same, or father and son with very similar names.<ref name="Carmack 2001b, p.181" />
K'otuja Q'uq'umatz married Xlem, daughter of the king of the [[Tz'utujil people|Tz'utujils]] of Malaj, a precolumbian settlement near modern-day [[San Lucas Tolimán]], on the shores of [[Lago de Atitlán|Lake Atitlán]].<ref>Carmack 2001a, p.159.</ref> Great magical powers were attributed to Q'uq'umatz and he was said to be able to transform himself into a snake, an eagle, a jaguar and blood.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.161">Carmack 2001a, p.161.</ref> Q'uq'umatz had several children, one of whom (K'iq'ab) became king after him.<ref name="Carmack 2001b, p.181" /> Q'uq'umatz was killed in battle against the K'oja Maya.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.161" />
Q'uq'umatz greatly expanded the K'iche' kingdom, first from Pismachi' and later from Q'umarkaj.<ref>Carmack 2001a, p.158.</ref> At this time, the K'iche's were closely allied with the [[Kaqchikel people|Kaqchikels]].<ref>Carmack 2001a, pp.158-159.</ref> Q'uq'umatz sent his daughter to marry the lord of the [[K'oja]], a Maya people based in the [[Sierra de los Cuchumatanes|Cuchumatan mountains]], somewhere between [[Sacapulas]] and [[Huehuetenango]].<ref>Carmack 2001a, pp.160-161.</ref> Instead of marrying her and submitting to the K'iche'-Kaqchikel alliance, Tekum Sik'om, the K'oja king, killed the offered bride.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.161" /> This act initiated a war between the K'iche'-Kaqchikel of Q'umarkaj and the K'oja.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.161" /> Q'uq'umatz died in the resulting battle against the K'oja.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.161" />
With the death of his father in battle against the K'oja, his son and heir K'iq'ab swore vengeance, and two years later he led the K'iche'-Kaqchikel alliance against his enemies, together with the ''Ajpop K'amha'' (king-elect).<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.162">Carmack 2001a, p.162.</ref> The K'iche'-led army entered K'oja at first light, killed Tekum Sik'om and captured his son.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.162" /> K'iq'ab recovered the [[Human trophy taking in Mesoamerica|bones]] of his father and returned to Q'umarkaj with many prisoners and all the [[jade use in Mesoamerica|jade]] and [[Metallurgy in pre-Columbian Mesoamerica|metal]] that the K'oja possessed, after conquering various settlements in the Sacapulas area, and the [[Mam people]] near [[Zaculeu]].<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.162" />
K'iq'ab was said to have had magical powers like his father.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.161"/> K'iq'ab was a particularly warlike king and during his reign he greatly expanded the kingdom to include [[Rabinal]], [[Cobán]] and [[Quetzaltenango]], and extended as far west as the Okos River, near the modern border between the [[Chiapas]] coast of Mexico and Guatemalan Pacific coast.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.162" /> With Kaqchikel help, the eastern frontier of the kingdom was pushed as far as the [[Motagua River]] and south as far as [[Escuintla]].<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.163">Carmack 2001a, p.163.</ref> However, he also suffered a humiliating rebellion that eventually resulted in the loss of his key [[Kaqchikel people|Kaqchikel]] allies.<ref>Carmack 2001a, pp.163-165.</ref> K'iq'ab died around 1475.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.165"/>
===Internal strife=== In 1470 a rebellion shook Q'umarkaj during a great celebration that saw a large gathering that included representatives of all the most important highland peoples.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.163" /> Two sons of K'iq'ab together with some of his vassals rebelled against their king, killing many high ranking lords, Kaqchikel warriors and members of the Kaweq lineage.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.164">Carmack 2001a, p.164.</ref> The rebels tried to kill K'iq'ab himself but he was defended by sons loyal to him in Pakaman, on the outskirts of the city.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.164" /> As a result of the rebellion, K'iq'ab was forced to make concessions to the rebelling K'iche' lords.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.165">Carmack 2001a, p.165.</ref> The newly empowered K'iche' lords turned against their Kaqchikel allies, who were forced to flee Q'umarkaj and found their own capital at [[Iximche]].<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.165" />
After the death of king K'iq'ab in 1475 the K'iche' were engaged in warfare against both the Tz'utujils and the Kaqchikels, perhaps in an attempt to recover the former power of Q'umarkaj.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.166" /> A short time after the death of K'iq'ab, under the leadership of Tepepul, Q'umarkaj attacked Iximche, the capital of the Kaqchikels, and suffered a disastrous defeat that greatly weakened the K'iche'.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.166">Carmack 2001a, p.166.</ref> After this Q'umarkaj never again directly challenged the Kaqchikels of Iximche.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.166" /> The next leader after Tepepul was Tekum, who was a son of K'iq'ab. who led the K'iche's against the Tz'utujils and was killed in battle near the south shore of Lake Atitlan.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.167">Carmack 2001a, p.167.</ref>
Late in the history of Q'umarkaj, the Nijaib appear to have been challenging the ruling Kaweq house for supremacy.<ref name="Carmack & Weeks 1981, p.331">Carmack & Weeks 1981, p.331.</ref>
===Conquest and destruction=== {{See also|Spanish conquest of Guatemala}} [[File:Alvarado.jpeg|thumb|right|Pedro de Alvarado, the [[conquistador]] who razed Q'umarkaj.]] In March 1524, the Spanish [[conquistador]] [[Pedro de Alvarado]] entered Q'umarkaj when invited by the remaining lords of the K'iche', after he defeated the K'iche' army in the [[Quetzaltenango]] valley, in a battle that had resulted in the death of [[Tecun Uman]], one of the four lords of the city.<ref>Sharer & Traxler 2006, pp.764-765. Recinos 1952, 1986, pp.68, 74.</ref> Alvarado feared that a trap had been laid for him by the K'iche' lords but entered the city anyway.<ref name="Sharer & Traxler 2006, pp.764-765"/> However, he encamped on the plain outside the city rather than accepting lodgings inside.<ref>Recinos 1952, 1986, p.74.</ref> Fearing the great number of K'iche' warriors gathered outside the city and that his cavalry would not be able to manoeuvre in the narrow streets of Q'umarkaj, he invited the highest lords of the city, Oxib-Keh (the ''ajpop'') and Beleheb-Tzy (the ''ajpop k'amha'') to visit him in his camp.<ref>Recinos 1952, 1986, p.75. Sharer & Traxler 2006, pp.764-765.</ref> As soon as they did so, he seized them and kept them as prisoners in his camp.<ref name="Recinos 1952, 1986, p.75">Recinos 1952, 1986, p.75.</ref> The K'iche' warriors, seeing their lords taken prisoner, attacked the Spaniards' indigenous allies and managed to kill one of the Spanish soldiers.<ref name="Recinos 1952, 1986, p.75" /> At this point Alvarado decided to have the captured K'iche' lords burnt to death, he then proceeded to burn the entire city.<ref>Recinos 1952, 1986, pp.74-5. Sharer & Traxler 2006, pp.764-765.</ref>
===Modern history=== The site was extensively documented in the colonial era. [[Francisco Ximénez]], who first revealed the K'iche' epic [[Popul Vuh]] to the world, visited Q'umarkaj in the final years of the 17th century.<ref>Carmack 2001a, pp.356-357.</ref> Miguel Rivera y Maestre wrote a report of the site for the government of Guatemala in 1834.<ref name="Kelly 1996, p.201" /> In 1840 [[John Lloyd Stephens]] and [[Frederick Catherwood]] paid a brief visit to the site after reading Rivera y Maestre's report, and Catherwood mapped the site and produced a drawing of the Temple of Tohil.<ref name="Kelly 1996, p.201" /> In 1865, the French architect Cesar Daly mapped the five clustered sites that include Q'umarkaj, although the maps have since been lost.<ref name="Carmack & Weeks 1981, p.326" /> A more detailed survey of the site was made by [[Alfred P. Maudslay]] in 1887, being published between 1889 and 1902.<ref name="Kelly 1996, p.201" /> Archeological excavations were carried out in the 1950s and the 1970s.
Jorge F. Guillemín cleared the ruins in 1956, mapped the surviving structures, as well as mapping the central K'iche' region and Q'umarkaj's satellite sites.<ref name="Carmack & Weeks 1981, p.326" /><ref name="Kelly 1996, p.202">Kelly 1996, p.202.</ref> The [[State University of New York at Albany]] spent three seasons excavating the ruins in the early 1970s.<ref name="Kelly 1996, p.202"/> Kenneth Brown of the [[University of Houston]] started major excavations at Q'umarkaj in 1977.<ref>Carmack & Weeks 1981, p.324.</ref>
In 2003, the Proyecto Etnoarqueológico Q’um’arkaj ("Q'umarkaj Ethnoarchaeological Project") has worked to reconstruct the history and socio-political organisation of the city through archaeological studies combined with ethnohistorical investigations.<ref name="Putzeys&C08p2">Putzeys et al 2008, p.2.</ref>
The archaeological site is still used for traditional Maya ceremonies, and is one of the most popular destinations in Guatemala for this kind of ritual activity, especially at the [[solstice]]s and for the New Year.<ref name="Putzeys&C08p7">Putzeys et al 2008, p.7.</ref>
==Site description== [[File:Catherwood - Santa Cruz del Quiche - Qumarkaj - Tohil Temple.jpg|thumb|right|The Temple of Tohil as drawn by Frederick Catherwood in 1840]] The site can be visited, although little restoration work has been done to it. Various temple pyramids, the remains of palaces (mostly reduced to mounds of rubble) and a court for playing the [[Mesoamerican ballgame]] can be seen in the site core. In the Greater Q'umarkaj area there were four [[Mesoamerican ballcourt|ballcourt]]s, one in each of the four major political divisions of the city, testifying to the central role of the ballgame ritual in the sociopolitical organisation of the city.<ref>Fox 1991, p.213.</ref>
Cut stone originally facing the buildings was taken to build the new buildings of Santa Cruz del Quiché;<ref name="Kelly 1996, p.200" /> the ruins were still being mined for construction material through the late 19th century, doing extensive damage to the remains of the old buildings.
The major structures of Q'umarkaj were laid out around a plaza, which had a plaster floor.<ref name="ReferenceA">Coe 1999, p.190. Kelly 1996, p.200.</ref> The K'iche' colonnaded buildings at Q'umarkaj appear to indicate ties with the distant city of [[Mayapan]] in the [[Yucatan Peninsula]].<ref>Sharer & Traxler 2006, p.625.</ref> The parallels also include skull imagery, effigy figure censers, squatting figures and the generous application of stucco.<ref>Milbrath & Peraza Lope 2003, p.24.</ref> A combined aerial and surface analysis of the ruins has revealed a strongly patterned arrangement with repeating combinations of pyramids, long structures and multipatio residential complexes.<ref name="Carmack & Weeks 1981, p.330">Carmack & Weeks 1981, p.330.</ref> These repeating combinations appear to be linked to the different '' nimja'' lineages.<ref name="Carmack & Weeks 1981, p.330" /> In addition there appears to be a larger division of the site, separating it into northwestern and southwestern halves.<ref name="Carmack & Weeks 1981, p.329"/> The dividing line runs from the west along a street to the central plaza, crosses the ballcourt and the plaza, then separates the northern and eastern branches of the site up to the rim of the canyon on the eastern side.<ref>Carmack & Weeks 1981, pp.329-330.</ref> This larger site division places six ''nimja'' complexes in the northern half and six in the south, although this larger division may not have been strictly along lineage lines, since Kaweq-linked structures are found in both halves of the site.<ref>Carmack & Weeks 1981, pp.330-331.</ref> The Kaweq and their allies dominated most of the site, with the Nijaib occupying the eastern portion, possibly as far as the satellite site of Atalaya.<ref name="Carmack & Weeks 1981, p.331"/>
===Temple of Tohil=== [[Image:Utatlan3.jpg|left|thumb|The remains of the temple of Tohil at Q'umarkaj.]] The plaza was dominated by the Temple of [[Tohil]], who was a [[jaguar]] deity associated with the sun and with rain and was the patron deity of Q'umarkaj.<ref>Coe 1999, p.190. Carmack 2001a, p.358.</ref> This temple lies on the western side of the main plaza.<ref name="Kelly 1996, p.200" /> The standing remains are reduced to the rubble and mud core of the temple, with an opening where modern Maya still make offerings.<ref name="Kelly 1996, p.200" /> As late as the middle of the 19th century, this temple was much better preserved and was described by John Lloyd Stephens.<ref>Carmack 2001a, p.355.</ref> Originally the temple consisted of a steep pyramid with stairways on three sides, all except the west, and a temple building was on the summit.<ref name="Kelly 1996, p.200" /> The base was {{convert|33|ft|m}} on each side and the exterior of the building was covered in painted stucco.<ref>Carmack 2001a, pp.355, 358.</ref> Catherwood's copy of Rivera y Maestre's drawing of the temple showed the body of the pyramid divided into four [[talud-tablero]] terraces and 19 steps in each of the three stairways, while Rivera y Maestra's drawing depicts 24 steps and six terraces.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.356">Carmack 2001a, p.356.</ref> [[Francisco Ximénez]], writing at the end of the 17th century, described the temple as the tallest building in Q'umarkaj.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.356" /> The identity of the temple as that of Tohil was known during the lifetime of Ximénez, when 30 steps were visible in each stairway and the remains of the pillars that supported the temple roof were still standing.<ref>Carmack 2001a, p.357.</ref> The building style of the Temple of Tohil is similar to that of the most important temples of Mayapan and [[Chichen Itza]], far to the north in the Yucatan Peninsula.<ref>Carmack 2001a, p.358.</ref> The pillars possibly once supported an elaborate masonry roof.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.361">Carmack 2001a, p.361.</ref>
The Temple of Tohil was used for human sacrifice, the bodies of the sacrificial victims were probably hurled down the front stairway before being decapitated and the heads places on a [[Tzompantli|skull rack]].<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.360">Carmack 2001a, p.360.</ref> This ''tzumpan'' was likely to have been located immediately to the southeast of the temple, in an area that is now buried under rubble fallen from the temple itself.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.374"/>
An image of a jaguar was found painted onto the stucco of the temple, an animal that was a [[nahual]] of the ruling Kaweq dynasty.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.360" />
===Temple of Awilix=== [[File:Temple of Awilix.jpg|thumb|right|The Temple of Awilix.]] The Temple of [[Awilix]] is on the east side of the plaza.<ref name="Kelly 1996, p.200"/> Awilix was the patron goddess of the Nijaib lineage and is identified with Ixbalanque, one of the [[Maya Hero Twins|Hero Twins]] from the Popul Vuh.<ref>Carmack 2001a, p.362. Fox & Cook 1996, p.813.</ref> According to a drawing made by Rivera y Maestre, the temple of Awilix was not as tall as the temple of Tohil.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.362">Carmack 2001a, p.362.</ref> This structure was apparently the second most important temple in Q'umarkaj.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.362" /> Originally this temple was formed of a large rectangular platform supporting a smaller platform and a temple structure on the east side.<ref name="ReferenceB">Kelly 1996, p.200. Carmack 2001a, p.361.</ref> A wide stairway climbed the west side of the temple, it was flanked on the lower level by two large talud-tablero panels.<ref name="ReferenceB"/> The exterior stonework of the building has been completely stripped away.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.361" /> The temple is similar in form to a temple mound on the west side of the first plaza in [[Iximche]], the postclassic capital of the [[Kaqchikel people|Kaqchikel]] Maya.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.361" /> There were four principal phases of construction and there is evidence that the temple had been repaired various times prior to the Conquest.<ref>Carmack 2001a, pp.361-362.</ref> The floor under the third phase of construction had been painted dark green.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.362" /> Archaeological investigations found fragments of incense burners underneath the first building phase.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.362" />
===Temple of Jakawitz=== A large mound on the south side of the plaza was once the Temple of [[Jacawitz|Jakawitz]], a deity of the mountains and the patron of the Ajaw K'iche' lineage.<ref>Kelly 1996, p.200. Carmack 2001a, pp.367, 369.</ref> Like the other structures of Q'umarkaj, all the stone facing has been robbed, leaving only a rubble and mud core.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.367">Carmack 2001a, p.367.</ref> This structure was part of a complex that consisted of a patio enclosed by the temple on the northern side, a palace on the southern side and a long building on the east.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.367" /> The Jakawitz complex has not been investigated archaeologically.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.367" /> Drawings by Rivera y Maestre suggest that the temple was a narrow building with four or five terraces.<ref>Carmack 2001a, p.368.</ref>
===Temple of Q'uq'umatz=== The temple of [[Gukumatz|Q'uq'umatz]] was a circular temple of the [[Feathered Serpent (deity)|feathered serpent]], and a palace in honour of the Kawek lineage, the ruling dynasty of the city.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> The temple is now only a circular impression in the surface of the main plaza.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.364">Carmack 2001a, p.364.</ref> It is located directly between the temples of Tohil and Awilix, slightly north of the central axis of the Tohil temple and slightly south of the axis of the Awilix temple.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.364" /> From the traces left in the plaza it is evident that the temple consisted of a circular wall measuring {{convert|6|m|ft}} across, running around a circular platform, with a {{convert|1|m|ft|adj=on}} wide circular passage between the two.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.364" /> The whole structure probably once supported a roof and there were small stone platforms on the east and west sides of the temple, each about {{convert|1|m|ft}} wide.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.364" />
The priests of Q'uq'umatz were drawn from an important lineage among the ruling Kaweq dynasty and this was likely to have been a source of power and prestige for the Kaweq.<ref>Carmack 2001a, p.366.</ref> The temple of Q'uq'umatz must have been completely dismantled very soon after the Spanish Conquest since it is not mentioned by any of the Colonial era visitors, and early drawings of the site show only vegetation where the temple once stood.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.364"/> The tradition of circular temples dedicated to the Feathered Serpent deity was an ancient one in the Mesoamerican cultural region.<ref>Carmack 2001a, p.365.</ref>
===Ballcourt=== [[Image:Utatlan2.jpg|thumb|right|The central ballcourt of Q'umarkaj.]] The Ballcourt lies close to, and just south of, the temple of Tohil, on the southwest side of the plaza.<ref>Kelly 1996, p.200. Fox 1991, p.217.</ref> The ballcourt still retains its distinctive shape, although the structures have been robbed of their facing.<ref>Carmack 2001a, p.370.</ref> The visible ballcourt was one of four in Q'umarkaj and was administered by the Popol Winaq branch of the ruling Kaweq lineage.<ref>Fox 1991, p.213. Carmack 2001a, p.371.</ref> The ballcourt is aligned east-west with a length of {{convert|40|m|ft}}.<ref>Fox 1991, p.216.</ref> The ballcourt was located exactly between the palaces of the Kaweq and the Ajaw K'iche', which were located {{convert|15|m|ft}} to the north and the south of the ballcourt.<ref name="Fox 1991, p.217">Fox 1991, p.217.</ref> Correspondingly, the north range of the ballcourt appears to have been associated with the Kaweq lineage and the south range with the Ajaw K'iche' lineage.<ref>Fox 1991, p.223.</ref>
===Palaces=== A small palace belonging to the Nijaib lineage was located directly behind the temple of Awilix.<ref>Carmack 2001a, p.363.</ref> These lineage houses, ''nimja'', are found throughout the city of Q'umarkaj.<ref name="Fox 1991, p.217"/> As with the other buildings of the site, the outer stonework and plastering has been lost.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.375">Carmack 2001a, p.375.</ref> The ''nimja'' are long rectangular structures located beside the plazas upon {{convert|1|m|ft|adj=on}} high platforms.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.375" /> Upon these platforms, the palaces generally consisted of two levels, a lower roofed antechamber with a second, higher level supporting the main rooms of the structure.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.375" /> Some of the larger palaces had several stairways giving access to the antechamber, and multiple doors and pillars opening into the rooms of main building.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.375" />
Another ''nimja'' palace structure lies to the southeast of the main plaza.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.375" /> Excavations in 1972 uncovered a simple superstructure consisting of a room with a bench at the back and an altar in the middle.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.375" /> Six funerary urns were found in the remains of the palace, one of which was found near the altar and contained rich offerings that included a gold necklace.<ref>Carmack 2001a, pp.375-376.</ref> There were traces of hearths at each extreme of the main chamber.<ref>Carmack 2001a, p.376.</ref>
===Other structures=== In the central plaza there are traces of thirteen small platforms that once stood there.<ref>Carmack 2001a, p.372.</ref> Three of these, each measuring {{convert|2.5|m|ft}} wide, were located to the north of the Temple of K'ucumatz.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.373">Carmack 2001a, p.373.</ref> A line of five similar structures was also located to the south of the same temple, with an alternating pattern of a circular platform, then a square platform, followed by another circular platform and so on.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.373" /> There was a sixth small platform nearby, which was square in shape.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.373" /> These platforms appear to have served as altars.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.373" />
To the south of the line of platforms are the traces of two larger square platforms. One of these measured {{convert|10|m|ft}} on each side, the other measured {{convert|8|m|ft}} per side.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.373" /> A circular impression lies between these two platforms, which is all that remains of another platform, of a different type, that must have stood there.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.373" /> The larger platforms may also have served as auxiliary altars to those of the principle temples.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.374">Carmack 2001a, p.374.</ref>
A large square platform in the northwest section of the central plaza, measuring {{convert|18|m|ft}} on each side, it is located immediately behind the Temple of Tohil and stands {{convert|2|m|ft}} high.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.373" /> Although, typically for the site, the outer stonework has been robbed, there are the remains of six layers of plaster on the floor of the platform's upper surface.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.373" /> This platform has been identified as the ''sokib'al'', the platform of gladiators described in early sources.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.374" /> This platform seems to have been closely linked to the military lineages of the Kaweq, such as the Nima Rajpop Achij.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.375" />
Two large platforms lie in the southeastern section of the main plaza, their use remains unknown.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.375" />
===Caves=== [[Image:View out of the tunnel.jpg|thumb|right|Smoke filled tunnel under the ruins of Q'umarkaj.]] In addition, a series of three caves tunnel straight into the limestone immediately to the north of the site.<ref name="Kelly 1996, p.200" /> The first and most extensive cave is about 30 meters long with various altars carved into the rock inside. Some modern Quiché, although officially [[Roman Catholic]], still burn [[candle]]s and [[incense]] at the ruined temples.<ref>Carmack 2001a, pp.218-219.</ref> The caves may have represented ''Tulán Zuyuá'', the "Place of Seven Caves" described in the K'iche' origin legend recounted in the Popul Vuh.<ref name="Fox 1989, p.667"/>
==Satellite sites== A number of other archaeological sites are included within the area of Greater Q'umarkaj (usually referred to as Greater Utatlan).
===Chisalin=== Chisalin is alson known by the alternative names of Pilokab' and Muqwitz Pilokab'.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.221">Carmack 2001a, p.221.</ref> Chisalin is located a few hundred meters north of Q'umarkaj.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.221" /> The ruins are located on a narrow strip of land with an area of {{convert|110000|sqm|sqft}} surrounded by steep ravines.<ref>Carmack 2001a, pp.221-222.</ref> On the northeast side the strip is connected to a plateau that forms a part of the plain to the east of Q'umarkaj.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.221" /> Chisalin has a small, heavily eroded plaza, and the whole strip is occupied by ruins, with the exception of a small section.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.222"/>
===Pismachi'=== Pismachi' (sometimes referred to as Ismachi') occupies a small plateau {{convert|600|m|yd}} south of the site core and is surrounded by steep ravines.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.219">Carmack 2001a, p.219.</ref> The plateau is separated from the Q'umarkaj plateau by the ravine containing the Ismachi' river.<ref>Carmack 2001a, pp.219-220.</ref> Pismachi' was the K'iche' capital before it was moved to nearby Q'umarkaj, and was probably founded early in the 14th century.<ref>Carmack 2001a, p.155.</ref> Its location was never forgotten by the local K'iche's although it was from time to time lost by outside investigators.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.219" /> French missionary [[Charles Étienne Brasseur de Bourbourg]] located Pismachi' in the middle of the 19th century, it was then lost until it was relocated in 1956 by Jorge Guillemín, working in collaboration with the government of Guatemala, the location was reconfirmed by Robert Carmack in 1969.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.219" /> Although the Pismachi' plateau is twice the size of the Q'umarkaj plateau, the ruins occupy a small area on the southeast portion of the hilltop.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.219" /> The ruins are still used for the rituals of modern K'iche' shamans.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.219" />
===Atalaya=== Atalaya (Spanish for "watchtower") is located at a distance of {{convert|600|m|yd}} to the east of the site core.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.222">Carmack 2001a, p.222.</ref> The site was built upon four terraces that dominated the approach to Q'umarkaj, at the beginning of the eastern plain occupied by the modern town of Santa Cruz del Quiché.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, pp.222-223">Carmack 2001a, pp.222-223.</ref> The site was very small, covering an area of {{convert|3250|sqm|sqft}}.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.223">Carmack 2001a, p.223.</ref> A paved avenue (or [[sacbe]]) is said by locals to have passed the tower, which was closely linked to the Nijaib lineage.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, pp.222-223" /> Between Q'umarkaj and Atalaya there was a place where criminals were punished.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.222" /> Atalaya is used for modern K'iche' rituals and is the focus of local folklore, which relates that Tecún Umán is buried there and that it is haunted by [[Tzitzimitl|tzitzimit]] spirits.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.223" /> Towards the end of the 20th century the majority of the land making up the site still belonged to the Rojas family, descendents of the kings of Q'umarkaj.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.223" />
===Pakaman=== Pakaman is located {{convert|1000|m|yd}} east of Atalaya and {{convert|1.6|km|mi|0}} east of Q'umarkaj.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, pp.222-223" /> The same ''sakbe'' that passed the north side of Atalaya is said to pass south of Pakaman.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.223" /> The original name of Pakaman is likely to have been ''Panpetaq'' ("place of arrival") and was the first important outpost on the entry road to Q'umarkaj.<ref name="Carmack 2001a, p.223" />

<!-- None of the following disambiguation pages exist, so comment out the hatnotes until they do. {{Redirect|Slack Wire}} {{Redirect|Slackrope}} {{Redirect|Slack rope}} --> [[File:Con Colleano on a slack-wire, circa 1920.jpg|thumb|Con Colleano on a slack-wire, circa 1920]] '''Slackwire (Slack wire)''' is an [[acrobatic]] [[circus]] act, that involves the balancing skills of moving along a flexible/slack thin wire suspended in the air, connected to two anchor points. Not to be confused with [[Slackline|slacklining]].
==Description and setup ==
Usually "slack wire" utilizes a steel wire {{cvt|4|-|8|mm|frac=16}} in diameter fixed between two anchor points. It can have two single stands with two extending wire pieces each to install the apparatus in an arena, or two "A" frames stands with one extending wire piece for each. It can also be mounted between two trees at an appropriate distance apart or fixed to a ceiling or any points which are strong enough to hold a performer's weight.
Wire walking artists usually use soft shoes made of leather.
===Slack Rope (Slackrope)===
A slack rope is very similar to a slack wire. The difference between a slack rope and a slackwire is in the characteristics of rope and wire. A slack rope usually utilizes a rope {{cvt|10|-|20|mm|frac=16}} in diameter. For both slack wire and slack rope, there are pluses and minuses to do stunts. For example, it is easier and more comfortable to do "sliding" tricks on a wire than on a rope. On a Slack rope a performer can walk without shoes, but that is painful on a Slackwire. In addition, a Slack rope is very similar to a [[Cloud Swing]].
===Technique of Balance and Angle of Slackwire=== The technique of balance – a performer balances or moves on the wire while needing to control the wire beneath him from moving abruptly side to side, making continual adjustments. This skill is similar to balancing a stick on one’s head or on a finger. Each Slackwire performer usually uses his/her own preferred angle of slack and length of the wire.
The slack angle is the V-shaped angle created when a performer stands in the middle of the walking part of the wire. The angle depends on how long or short the wire is relative to the distance between two anchor points. This also affects the swing amplitude of the wire side to side. Some slackwire artists change the angle of the wire during their act. See video in which a Chinese artist performs on the Slackwire, changing the angles of the wire with the help of a winch several times during the performance. [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AOWo56CmYrI Video]
The degree of ease or difficulty for a performer to move the wire is dependent upon how thick the wire or rope is. The heavier the wire or rope, the more inertia is required to move it laterally, but also requires more force to contro; to movement or bring to bring it back to a place of rest.
===Skills=== The skills and stunts commonly performed on a slack Wire and slackrope include:
Beyond standing and walking artists can also do turns, lying own, knee stands, sliding, forward and backward rolls, splits, hand stands, including cartwheels, head stands. Props such as a ladder, chair, unicycle, bicycle, and even a rola-bola are incorporated into some acts.
Some more advanced Slackwire stunts are done while the wire is swinging, including standing, handstands, and walking. Slackwire balancing skills also can be combined with tricks as various kinds of juggling, balancing a stick on the performer’s head, playing a musical instrument, etc. Some of the same skills can be seen in [[Cloud Swing]] or [[Trapeze]] acts as well.
====Jumping Rope on a Slack Wire==== [[Skipping rope|Jumping Rope]] is popular in many circus acts. The skill has been performed on the ground in many variations, and on a [[Tightrope walking|Tightrope]], on a [[Slacklining|slackline]], but difficult on a slackwire because the wire moves when the performer jumps up and there is no way to control the swing and position of the wire when landing. This makes such stunts as somersaults and acrobatic tumbling virtually impossible.
Jumping rope on a slackwire was first accomplished in 1985. The only person to do the stunt is [[Sergey Alexandrovich Pavlov|Sergey Pavlov (the clown LALALA)]] Sergey has even been able to complete up to 7 consecutive jumps.
*[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hYoqMWJNThA Video - S. Pavlov - 4 skips and dancing] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=URWheYZktVE Video - S. Pavlov - 5 skips]
==Similarities and Differences==
===Slackwire and Tightrope=== Slackwire and tightrope appear to be very similar skills to walking and balancing on a thin wire/rope. But actually the technique of balance is very different between them. [[File:Korea-Jeonju-Jultagi-02.jpg|thumb|250px|Tightrope performance (Korea)]] The citation from [[Tightrope walking]]: "Slackwire and tight wire/tightrope require different balancing techniques: tightrope performers keep their balance by shifting their weight over the rigid tight wire, while slackwire performers use a precise swinging motion to move the relaxed slackwire under their center of mass." Because of this, an artist who works on a tightrope cannot easily make a transition to the Slackwire. He/she needs to spend time to train himself/herself to balance in this different manner and vice versa for artists working first on a slackwire.
Some tight-wire artists demonstrate a stunt called “the swings”. An artist takes the position on the wire, then his assistant reduces the tightness/tension of the wire and the artist demonstrates “swings.” The tight wire is adjusted to a slightly less tight condition. This stunt involves multiple skills to maintain balance. After the demonstration the assistant adjusts the wire back to its original tightness/tension.
[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=q5znx0XY9jo video - Volzhansky family "Prometheus"/"Прометей", 1977" (timer: 4:55)]
The same stunt can also be demonstrated on a slackline.
===Slack Wire and [[Slacklining|Slackline]]=== [[File:Slackline in the sun.jpg|thumb|Slacklining in a park]] There is confusion that Slackline means the same as Slackwire. They are not the same. They are different kinds of apparatuses that require different techniques of balancing.
The differences between Slackwire and Slackline:
* Slackwire utilizes a steel wire {{cvt|4|-|8|mm|frac=16}} in diameter, while Slackline utilizes a nylon webbing/strap approximately {{convert|2|in|-1|order=flip|abbr=in}} in width. * Different Techniques of balancing: A slackwire has a loop and can be used like a swing, but a slackline has no loop. The line is stretched tight between two anchor points like a tightrope and can only swing within a very small amplitude.
* A slackline can be used like a trampoline, allowing for an easy landing on the line after a jump. In contrast, a Slackwire cannot be used like a trampoline, because when a performer jumps up from the loop of wire it will swing away with no way to anticipate its location upon landing.
[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TSfGS7rv3co Video -(slacklining) She Walks the Line: Braving a Thin Rope Between Mountains]
(see also about the differences [[tightrope walking]])
==The World Records== *[[Sergey Alexandrovich Pavlov|Sergey Pavlov]] – Jumping Rope on a Slackwire – 3, 4, 5, 7 consecutively skips (1985–2017)
==External links== *[http://www.juggling.org/help/circus-arts/slackrope.html Slack Rope] at juggling.org

[[File:Elias Brenner.jpg|thumb|[[Elias Brenner]], the most likely candidate as an author of the chronicle.]] '''Suomen kronikka''' ([[Latin|lat]]. ''Chronicon Finlandiae'', [[English language|eng]]. ''The Chronicle of Finland'') is a [[chronicle]] written in 1670s describing the history of Finland until [[Middle Ages|middle ages]].
The writer is unknown, but the most likely candidate is painter [[Elias Brenner]]. He was known patron of Finns and Finland and his stages of life support the possibility. If Brenner is the author of the chronicle, it has been written between 1672-1674. The original chronicle was published in [[Latin]] in 1728 by [[Christian Nettelblad]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Messenius, Johannes: Suomen, Liivinmaan ja Kuurinmaan vaiheita, sekä tuntemattoman tekijän Suomen kronikka.|last=Translated to Finnish from Latin: Martti Linna, Jorma Lagerstedt, Erkki Palmén.|first=|publisher=Historian ystäväin liitto. Suomalaisen Kirjallisuuden Seuran toimituksia 467. Historiallinen kirjasto 21|year=1988|isbn=951-717-495-0|location=Helsinki|pages=123-134}}</ref>
The chronicle was aimed at creating a great past to Finns who were still under Swedish rule. This is possibly the reason that it was only printed after the death of the author and the fall of the [[Swedish Empire|Swedish empire]].<ref name=":0" />
The author mainly uses sagas and historians as sources of the chronicle, such as [[Saxo Grammaticus]], [[Bartholomeus Anglicus]], [[Johannes Magnus]], [[Olaus Magnus]], [[Anders Bure]], [[Michael Wexionius]] and [[Snorri Sturluson]].<ref name=":0" />

{{Other uses}} {{Wiktionary|supine}}
In [[grammar]], a '''supine''' is a form of [[verbal noun]] used in some languages. The term is most often used for [[Latin]], where it is one of the four [[principal parts]] of a verb.
==Latin== {{see also|Latin conjugation#Supine|Latin syntax#The supine}}
There are two supines, I (first) and II (second). They are originally the [[Accusative case|accusative]] and [[Ablative case|ablative]] forms of a [[verbal noun]] in the [[Latin declensions|fourth declension]], respectively. The first supine ends in ''-um''. It has two uses. The first is with verbs of motion and indicates purpose. For example, "Gladiatores adierunt '''pugnatum'''" is Latin for "The gladiators have come '''to fight'''", and "Nuntii '''gratulatum''' et '''cubitum''' venerunt" is Latin for "The messengers came '''to congratulate''' and '''to sleep'''". The second usage is in the [[Future tense|future]] [[Passive voice|passive]] [[infinitive]], for example "'''amatum iri'''" means "to be about to be loved". It mostly appears in indirect statements, for example "credidit se '''necatum iri'''", meaning "he believed that he was '''going to be killed'''".
The second supine can be used with adjectives but it is rarely used, and only a few verbs traditionally take it. It is derived from the ''dativus finalis'', which expresses purpose, or the ''ablativus respectivus'', which indicates in what respect. It is the same as the first supine without the final ''-m'' and with lengthened "u". "Mirabile dictū", for example, means "amazing to say", where ''dictū'' is a supine form.
==Germanic languages== In [[English grammar]], the term "supine" is sometimes used to refer to the [[to-infinitive|''to''-infinitive]], in sentences like "'''To err''' is human; '''to forgive''' divine."
In [[Swedish language|Swedish]], the supine is used with an [[auxiliary verb]] to produce some compound verb forms ([[perfect (grammar)|perfect]] forms). ''See'' [[Swedish grammar#Supine form|Swedish grammar]].
In [[Icelandic language|Icelandic]] grammar, ''sagnbót'' (usually translated as "supine") is a verbal form identical to the neuter participle, used to form certain verb tenses.
==Finnic languages== In [[Estonian language|Estonian]], the supine is called "ma-tegevusnimi" (lit. "ma-action name") because all the words in supine have "ma" in the end (as in "tegema", "jooksma", "kõndima"), and they act similarly to the Latin example. The supine is also the common [[dictionary form]] for verbs.
==Romance languages== In [[Romanian language|Romanian]], the supine generally corresponds to an English construction like ''for doing'': "Această carte este '''de citit'''" means "This book is '''for reading'''".
==Slavic languages== The [[Slovene language|Slovene]] and the [[Lower Sorbian language|Lower Sorbian]] supine is used after verbs of movement; ''see'' [[Slovenian verbs#Supine and Infinitive (Namenilnik in nedoločnik)|Slovenian verbs]]. The supine was used in [[Proto-Slavic language|Proto-Slavic]] but it was replaced in most [[Slavic languages]] by the [[infinitive]] in later periods.
==Baltic languages== In some dialects of [[Lithuanian language|Lithuanian]], the supine is used with verbs of motion to indicate purpose: ''Moterys eina miestan duonos '''pirktų''' '', which means "The women are going to the town to buy some bread" (more archaic forms are '''pirktun''' and '''pirktum'''). The standard language uses the infinitive, '''pirkti''', instead of the supine. In the past, the supine was much more widespread form than now.
==See also== *[[Gerund]] *[[Non-finite verb]] {{lexical categories|state=collapsed}}

'''The American Rationalist''' is a bi-monthly journal of secular humanist opinion and commentary published by the [[Center for Inquiry]]. [[S. T. Joshi]] is the current editor and writes the "Stupidity Watch" column for the journal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://therationalist.eu.org/kk.php/d,139|title=European Union: The Rationalist}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Stupidity-Watch-Atheist-Religion-Politics/dp/1544821646|title=The Stupidity Watch}}</ref><ref name="Amrat">{{cite journal| journal = The American Rationalist| volume = 63| issue = 3| year = 2017| pages = 2| title = A Journal of Freethought}}</ref><ref name="Mencken">{{cite book| title =The Collected Drama of H. L. Mencken: Plays and Criticism| edition = | last = Joshi| first = S. T. | coauthors = | year = 2012| publisher = Scarecrow Press| id = | pages =269}}</ref>
Feature articles cover a wide range of topics from a freethought viewpoint including science and religion, separation of church and state, and applied philosophy. Regular contributors include well-known scholars in the fields of science and philosophy.
==Notable columnists== Regular columnists include: <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thinkatheist.com/profile/DrDonaldRBurleson|title=Think Atheist}}</ref><ref name="Amrat2">{{cite journal| journal = The American Rationalist| volume = 63| issue = 3| year = 2017| pages = 2| title = A Journal of Freethought}}</ref><ref name="Amrat3">{{cite journal| journal = The American Rationalist| volume = 62| issue = 4| year = 2016| pages = 1| title = American Rationalist}}</ref> *[[Robert M. Price]] *[[William R. Harwood]] *[[S. T. Joshi]]

{{About|the book series|other uses|The Hunger Games (disambiguation)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=November 2014}} {{Pp-semi-vandalism|small=yes}} {{Italic title}} {{Infobox book series |name=''The Hunger Games'' |books={{plainlist| * ''[[The Hunger Games (novel)|The Hunger Games]]'' (2008) * ''[[Catching Fire]]'' (2009) * ''[[Mockingjay]]'' (2010) }} |image=The Hunger Games cover.jpg |caption=A complete set of ''The Hunger Games'' trilogy |author=[[Suzanne Collins]] |country=United States |language=English |genre=[[Dystopian fiction|Dystopian]], [[Adventure novel|adventure]], [[science fiction]], [[drama]], [[Action (fiction)|action]] |publisher=[[Scholastic Corporation|Scholastic]] |pub_date=2008–2010 |media_type=Print ([[hardcover]] and [[paperback]]), [[audiobook]], [[e-book]] |number_of_books=3 }}
'''''The Hunger Games''''' is a [[trilogy]] of [[Young adult fiction|young adult]] [[Dystopian fiction|dystopian]] novels written by American novelist [[Suzanne Collins]]. The series is set in [[The Hunger Games universe|''The Hunger Games'' universe]], and follows young characters [[Katniss Everdeen]] and [[Peeta Mellark]].
The novels in the trilogy are titled [[The Hunger Games (novel)|''The Hunger Games'']] (2008), ''[[Catching Fire]]'' (2009), and ''[[Mockingjay]]'' (2010). The novels have all been developed into [[The Hunger Games (film series)|films]] starring [[Jennifer Lawrence]], with the film adaptation of ''Mockingjay'' split into two parts. The first two books in the series were both [[The New York Times Best Seller list|''New York Times'' best sellers]], and ''Mockingjay'' topped all US bestseller lists upon its release.<ref>{{cite news | title=Children's Books | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/12/27/books/bestseller/bestchildren.html | newspaper=[[The New York Times]] | date= December 27, 2009 | accessdate=December 31, 2009 | first=Gregory | last=Cowles}}</ref><ref>{{cite press release | title=Mockingjay Tops All National Bestseller Lists with Sales of More Than 450,000 Copies in its First Week of Publication | url=http://mediaroom.scholastic.com/node/363 | publisher=Scholastic | date=September 2, 2010 | accessdate=May 7, 2011}}</ref> By the time [[The Hunger Games (film)|the film adaptation]] of ''The Hunger Games'' was released in 2012, the publisher had reported over 26 million ''Hunger Games'' trilogy books in print, including movie tie-in books.<ref>{{cite news | first=Karen | last=Springen | title=The Hunger Games Franchise: The Odds Seem Ever in Its Favor | url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/childrens/childrens-book-news/article/51167-the-hunger-games-franchise-the-odds-seem-ever-in-its-favor.html | newspaper=[[Publishers Weekly]] | date=March 22, 2012 | accessdate=April 11, 2012}}</ref>
''The Hunger Games'' universe is a [[dystopia]] set in [[The Hunger Games universe#Panem|Panem]], a country consisting of the wealthy Capitol and 12 districts in varying states of poverty. Every year, children from the districts are selected to participate in a compulsory televised [[battle royal]]e death match called [[The Hunger Games universe#The Hunger Games|The Hunger Games]].
The novels were all well received. In August 2012, the series ranked second, exceeded only by the ''[[Harry Potter]]'' series in [[NPR]]'s poll of the top 100 teen novels, which asked voters to choose their favorite young adult books.<ref>{{Cite press release |url=https://www.npr.org/2012/08/07/157795366/your-favorites-100-best-ever-teen-novels |title=Your Favorites: 100 Best-Ever Teen Novels| publisher=NPR | date=August 7, 2012 |accessdate=August 10, 2012 }}</ref> On August 17, 2012, [[Amazon.com|Amazon]] announced ''The Hunger Games'' trilogy as its top seller, surpassing the record previously held by the ''Harry Potter'' series.<ref>{{Cite news| url=http://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/08/17/amazon-crowns-hunger-games-as-its-top-seller-surpassing-harry-potter-series/ | work=The New York Times | first=Julie | last=Bosman | title=Amazon Crowns 'Hunger Games' as Its Top Seller, Surpassing Harry Potter Series | date=August 17, 2012}}</ref> {{As of|2014}}, the trilogy has sold more than 65 million copies in the U.S. alone (more than 28 million copies of ''The Hunger Games'', more than 19 million copies of ''Catching Fire'', and more than 18 million copies of ''Mockingjay''). ''The Hunger Games'' trilogy has been sold into 56 territories in 51 languages to date.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thewrap.com/hunger-games-mockingjay-part-1-set-for-world-premiere-in-london/|title='Hunger Games: Mockingjay - Part 1' Set for World Premiere in London|work=TheWrap|accessdate=March 3, 2015}}</ref>
==Setting== {{Main|Fictional universe of The Hunger Games}} ''The Hunger Games'' trilogy takes place in an unspecified future time, in the dystopian, [[Apocalypse|post-apocalyptic]] nation of Panem, located in [[North America]].<ref>{{Cite book|last=Collins|first=Suzanne|title=The Hunger Games|year=2008|publisher=[[Scholastic Corporation|Scholastic Press]]|isbn=0-439-02348-3| page=18}}</ref> The country consists of a wealthy Capitol city, located in the [[Rocky Mountains]],<ref name="HG_41">{{Cite book|last=Collins|first=Suzanne|title=The Hunger Games|year=2008|publisher=[[Scholastic Corporation|Scholastic Press]]|isbn=0-439-02348-3|page=41}}</ref> surrounded by twelve (originally thirteen) poorer districts ruled by the Capitol. The Capitol is lavishly rich and technologically advanced, but the districts are in varying states of poverty. The trilogy's narrator and protagonist [[Katniss Everdeen]], lives in District 12, the poorest region of Panem, located in [[Appalachia]],<ref name="HG_41"/> where people regularly die of starvation. As punishment for a past rebellion against the Capitol (called the "Dark Days"), in which District 13 was supposedly destroyed, one boy and one girl from each of the twelve remaining districts, between the ages of 12 and 18, are selected by lottery to compete in an annual pageant called the Hunger Games. The Games are a televised event in which the participants, called "tributes", are forced to fight to the death in a dangerous public arena. The winning tribute and his/her home district are then rewarded with food, supplies, and riches. The purposes of the Hunger Games are to provide entertainment for the Capitol and to remind the districts of the Capitol's power and lack of [[remorse]], [[forgetfulness]], and [[forgiveness]] for the failed rebellion of the current competitors' ancestors.
===Structure=== Each book in ''The Hunger Games'' trilogy has three sections of nine chapters each. Collins has said this format comes from her playwriting background, which taught her to write in a [[three-act structure]]; her previous series, ''[[The Underland Chronicles]]'', was written in the same way. She sees each group of nine chapters as a separate part of the story, and comments still call those divisions "act breaks".<ref>{{cite interview |last=Collins |first=Suzanne |title=Similarities To Underland |url=http://www.scholastic.com/thehungergames/videos/similarities-to-underland.htm |type=Interview: Video |work=[[Scholastic Canada]] |accessdate=June 15, 2010}}</ref>
===Origins=== Collins says she drew inspiration for the series from both classical and contemporary sources. Her main classical source of [[Artistic inspiration|inspiration]] is the Greek myth of [[Theseus]] and the [[Minotaur]], in which, as a punishment for past crimes, [[Minos]] forces [[Athens]] to sacrifice seven youths and seven maidens to the Minotaur, which kills them in a vast [[labyrinth]]. Collins says that even as a child, she was stunned by the idea since "it was just so cruel" to force Athens to sacrifice its own children.
Collins also cites as a classical inspiration the Roman [[gladiator]] games. She feels three key elements create a good game: an all powerful and ruthless government, people forced to fight to the death, and the game's role as a source of popular entertainment.<ref name="classical">{{cite web|url=http://www.scholastic.com/thehungergames/videos/classical-inspiration.htm |title=Video: Classical Inspiration – The Hunger Games by Suzanne Collins|publisher=[[Scholastic Corporation|Scholastic]]|accessdate=September 4, 2010}}</ref>
A contemporary source of inspiration was Collins' recent fascination with [[Reality TV|reality television programs]]. She says they are like ''The Hunger Games'' because the Games are not just entertainment but also a reminder to the districts of their rebellion. On a tired night, Collins says that while she was channel-surfing the television, she saw people competing for some prize and then saw footage of the [[Iraq War]]. She described how the two combined in an "unsettling way" to create her first ideas for the series.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scholastic.com/thehungergames/videos/contemporary-inspiration.htm|title=Video: Contemporary Inspiration – The Hunger Games by Suzanne Collins|publisher=Scholastic|accessdate=September 4, 2010}}</ref>
==Trilogy== ===''The Hunger Games''=== {{Main|The Hunger Games (novel)}} ''The Hunger Games'' is the first book in the series and was released on September 14, 2008.
''The Hunger Games'' follows 16-year-old [[Katniss Everdeen]], a girl from District 12 who volunteers for the 74th Hunger Games in place of her younger sister [[Primrose Everdeen]]. Also selected from District 12 is [[Peeta Mellark]]. They are mentored by their district's only living victor, [[Haymitch Abernathy]], who won 24 years earlier and has since led a solitary life of [[alcoholism]].
Peeta confesses his longtime secret love for Katniss in a televised interview prior to the Games. This revelation stuns Katniss, who harbors feelings for [[Gale Hawthorne]], her friend and hunting partner. Haymitch advises her to feign feelings for Peeta in order to gain wealthy sponsors who can provide crucial supplies to the "[[star-crossed lovers]]" during the Games.
In the arena, Katniss allies with [[Rue (The Hunger Games)|Rue]], a young tribute from District 11 who reminds Katniss of her kid sister. When Rue is killed, Katniss places flowers around her body as an act of defiance toward the Capitol. Then the remaining tributes are alerted to a rule change that allows tributes from the same district to win as a team. Katniss finds a seriously wounded Peeta and nurses him back to health. When all of the other tributes are dead, the rule change is abruptly revoked. With neither willing to kill the other, Katniss comes up with a solution: a double suicide by eating poisonous berries. This forces the authorities to concede just in time to save their lives. During and after the Games, Katniss develops genuine feelings for Peeta and struggles to reconcile them with what she feels for Gale.
Haymitch warns her that the danger is far from over. The authorities are furious at being made fools of, and the only way to try to allay their anger is to pretend that her actions were because of her love for Peeta. On the journey home, Peeta is dismayed to learn of the deception.
===''Catching Fire ''=== {{Main|Catching Fire}} ''Catching Fire'' is the second installment in the series, released on September 1, 2009.
In ''Catching Fire'', which begins six months after the conclusion of ''The Hunger Games'', Katniss learns that her defiance in the previous novel has started a chain reaction that has inspired rebellion in the districts. President Snow threatens to harm Katniss' family and friends if she does not help to defuse the unrest in the districts and marry Peeta. Meanwhile, Peeta has become aware of Katniss' disingenuous love for him, but he has also been informed of Snow's threats, so he promises to help keep up the act to spare the citizens of District 12. Katniss and Peeta tour the districts as victors and plan a public wedding. While they follow Snow's orders and keep up the ruse, Katniss inadvertently fuels the rebellion, and the [[Mockingjays|mockingjay]] pin she wears becomes its symbol. District by district, the citizens of Panem begin to stage uprisings against the Capitol. Snow announces a special 75th edition of the Hunger Games—known as the [[Quarter Quell]]—in which Katniss and Peeta are forced to compete with other past victors, effectively canceling the wedding. At Haymitch's urging, the pair teams up with several other tributes, and manages to destroy the arena and escape the Games. Katniss is rescued by the rebel forces from District 13, and Gale informs her that the Capitol has destroyed District 12, and captured both Peeta and their District 7 ally, [[Johanna Mason]]. Katniss ultimately learns—to her surprise—that she had inadvertently been an integral part of the rebellion all along; her rescue had been jointly planned by Haymitch, [[List of The Hunger Games characters#Plutarch Heavensbee|Plutarch Heavensbee]], and [[Finnick Odair]], among others. After some hesitation Katniss joins the rebels.
===''Mockingjay''=== {{Main|Mockingjay}} ''Mockingjay'', the third and final book in ''The Hunger Games'' series, was released on August 24, 2010.
Most of the districts have rebelled against the Capitol, led by District 13 and its President [[List of The Hunger Games characters#Alma Coin|Alma Coin]]. The Capitol lied about the district being destroyed in the Dark Days. After a [[Mexican standoff]] with the Capitol, the District 13 residents took to living underground and rebuilding their strength. The District 12 survivors find shelter with them. Katniss, after seeing first-hand the destruction wrought on her district, agrees to become the "Mockingjay", the symbol of the rebellion. She sets conditions, however. Peeta, Johanna Mason, [[Annie Cresta]], and [[List of The Hunger Games characters#Enobaria|Enobaria]], fellow Games victors captured by the Capitol, are to be granted immunity. Katniss also demands the privilege of killing Snow, but Coin only agrees to flip for the honor.
For her sake, a rescue mission is mounted that succeeds in rescuing Peeta, Johanna and Annie. However, Peeta has been [[Mind control|brainwashed]] to kill Katniss, and he tries to choke her to death upon their reunion. He undergoes experimental treatment to try to cure him.
After she recovers, Katniss and a team known as the Star Squad, composed of Gale, Peeta, Finnick, a [[Film crew|camera crew]], and various other soldiers, are assigned to film propaganda in relatively quiet combat zones. Katniss, however, decides to go to the Capitol to kill Snow, pretending that Coin gave her that mission. Most of the squad are killed along the way, including recently married Finnick. As Katniss approaches Snow's mansion, she sees a group of Capitol children surrounding it as [[human shield]]s. Suddenly a hovercraft drops silver parachutes on the children, who reach for them, hoping they bear food. Some of the parachutes explode, creating carnage. The advancing rebels send in [[medic]]s, including Prim. Then the rest of the parachutes blow up, killing Prim, just as she spots her sister.
Later, Katniss, also injured, awakens from a [[coma]] to learn that the rebels have won, and Snow is awaiting execution at her hands. When she meets Snow by chance, he claims that it was Coin who secretly ordered the bombings in order to strip away the support of his remaining followers. Coin then asks the surviving victors to vote on a final Hunger Games, involving the children of high-ranking Capitol officials (including Snow's granddaughter). Katniss and Haymitch cast the deciding votes in favor of the scheme. However, at what is supposed to be Snow's execution, Katniss instead kills Coin with her bow. Snow laughs, then dies.
Katniss is tried, but the jury believes she was mentally unfit, and she is sent home to District 12. Both Katniss' mother and Gale take jobs in other districts. Peeta regains his sanity. Katniss settles down with him, and after many years of persuasion by him, she finally agrees to have children. They have a girl and then a boy.
==Popular culture== ===Critical reception=== All three books have been favorably received. Praise has focused on the addictive quality, especially of the first book,<ref name="King">{{cite news|first=Stephen|last=King|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20223443,00.html|title=The Hunger Games review|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=September 8, 2008|accessdate=November 26, 2010}}</ref> and the action.<ref>{{cite web|first=Francisca|last=Goldsmith|url=http://www.booklistonline.com/ProductInfo.aspx?pid=2739783|title=The Hunger Games|publisher=[[Booklist]]|accessdate=November 26, 2010}}</ref> [[John Green (author)|John Green]] of ''[[The New York Times]]'' compared ''The Hunger Games'' with [[Scott Westerfeld]]'s [[The Uglies series|''The Uglies'' series]].<ref>{{cite news | author=John Green | authorlink = John Green (author) | title=Scary New World | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/09/books/review/Green-t.html | newspaper=[[The New York Times]] | date=November 7, 2008 | accessdate=January 3, 2011}}</ref> ''Catching Fire'' was praised for improving upon the first book.<ref>{{cite news |first=Gabrielle|last=Zevin|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/10/11/books/review/Zevin-t.html |title=Constant Craving|work = The New York Times |date=October 9, 2009|accessdate=November 26, 2010}}</ref> ''Mockingjay'' was praised for its portrayal of violence,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://shelf-life.ew.com/2010/08/24/mockingjay-review-spoiler-alert/|title='Mockingjay' review: Spoiler alert!|date=August 24, 2010|work = Entertainment Weekly |accessdate=November 26, 2010}}</ref> world building, and romantic intrigue.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/reviews/single/59715-mockingjay-.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100826091818/http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/reviews/single/59715-mockingjay-.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=August 26, 2010|title=Mockingjay|work=[[Publishers Weekly]]|accessdate=November 26, 2010|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
The series received criticism regarding its [[reality TV]] "death game" theme being derivative of works such as ''[[Battle Royale (novel)|Battle Royale]]'', ''[[The Running Man (novel)|The Running Man]]'', ''[[The Long Walk]]'',<ref name="King"/> and ''[[Series 7: The Contenders]]''.<ref>{{cite web|author=O'Hehir, Andrew|url=http://www.salon.com/2012/03/14/what_came_before_the_hunger_games/|title=What came before 'The Hunger Games'|publisher=[[Salon (website)|Salon]]|date=March 13, 2012|accessdate=October 7, 2014}}</ref> The series was also criticized for the romantic plotline: Rollie Welch of Ohio's ''[[The Plain Dealer]]'' criticized the characters' lack of resolute behavior,<ref>{{cite news|first=Rollie|last=Welch|url=http://www.cleveland.com/bookreviews/plaindealer/index.ssf?/base/entertainment-1/125213948127050.xml&coll=2|title='Catching Fire' brings back Suzanne Collins's kindhearted killer|work=[[The Plain Dealer]]|date=September 6, 2009|location=[[Brooklyn, Ohio]]|accessdate=November 26, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68rJLJZUd?url=http://www.cleveland.com/bookreviews/plaindealer/index.ssf?%2Fbase%2Fentertainment-1%2F125213948127050.xml|archivedate=July 2, 2012|df=mdy-all}}</ref> and Jennifer Reese of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' stated that there was little distinction between Peeta and Gale and the series lacked the "erotic energy" seen in the ''[[Twilight (novel series)|Twilight]]'' series.<ref>{{cite news|first=Jennifer|last=Reese|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20300507,00.html|title=Catching Fire review|work = Entertainment Weekly |date=August 28, 2009|accessdate=November 26, 2010}}</ref>
J.C. Maçek III of ''[[PopMatters]]'' stated "While [[The Hunger Games (film series)|the film saga]] does capture the [[action (fiction)|action]] of ''The Hunger Games'', the novels are most assuredly the heart of the story. They are nothing less than 'The Writer’s Cut' of the films themselves."<ref name=PM>{{cite web|work=[[PopMatters]]|url=http://www.popmatters.com/column/the-hunger-games-the-writers-cut-really-is-better/|title='The Hunger Games': The Writer’s Cut Really Is Better|date=20 June 2016|first=J.C.|last=Maçek III}}</ref>
The last book, ''Mockingjay'', was criticized by Dan Shade of ''[[SF Site]]'', who felt that Katniss is a weaker character than her comrades and less resolute in her journey to the Capitol, and that with respect to her vendetta against President Snow, her actions in the finale are inconsistent with her established character.<ref>Shade, Dan (2010). [https://www.sfsite.com/11a/mb331.htm "Mockingjay"]. [[SF Site]].</ref>

===Culture=== ;Influence in Thailand A gesture (a raised up hand with three middle fingers pressed together) used in ''The Hunger Games'' trilogy to express unity with people striving to survive, was used in 2014 by anti-government protestors in [[Thailand]], at least seven of whom were arrested for it.<ref name="sput_Peop">{{cite web| title = People arrested in Thailand for gesture from 'Hunger Games' film series| author = Olga Zamanskaya| website= [[Voice of Russia]]| date = 10 June 2014| accessdate = 6 March 2015| url = http://sputniknews.com/voiceofrussia/news/2014_06_10/People-arrested-in-Thailand-for-gesture-from-Hunger-Games-film-series-6675/}}</ref>

{{Infobox book | name = The Oxford Companion to Classical Literature | image = File:The Oxford Companion to Classical Literature.jpg | caption = Cover of the first edition | author = [[Paul Harvey (diplomat)|Sir Paul Harvey]] | country = | language = English | series = | subject = | publisher = [[Oxford University Press]] | pub_date = 1937 | media_type = Print | pages = | isbn = | oclc = | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''The Oxford Companion to Classical Literature''''' is a book in the [[Book series|series]] of [[Oxford Companions]] produced by [[Oxford University Press]]. It is compiled and edited by [[Paul Harvey (diplomat)|Sir Paul Harvey]], Fellow of [[St Anne's College, Oxford]] and lecturer in Classical Languages at the [[University of Oxford]].
The book provides an alphabetically arranged reference to [[classics|classical]] [[literature]]. The second edition was published in 1989, the third in 2011.
{{ISBN|0-19-866121-5}}.

{{nihongo|'''''The Window of Orpheus'''''|オルフェウスの窓|Orufeusu no Mado}}, also known as '''''Orpheus no Mado''''' or '''''Das Fenster von Orpheus''''', is a Japanese historical [[manga]] series written and illustrated by [[Riyoko Ikeda]]. It was published by [[Shueisha]] in ''[[Margaret (magazine)|Margaret]]'' from 1975 to 1981, and collected in 18 [[tankōbon|bound volumes]]. It takes place in [[Germany]], [[Austria]] and [[Russia]] with the backdrop story of the [[Russian Revolution of 1917|Russian Revolution]].
== Story == The story begins in [[Regensburg]], Germany in 1903. There is a rumor at the all-boys Catholic S. Sebastian Music Institute that if someone looks through a window known as The Window of Orpheus in one of the towers and sees a beautiful girl through it, he will fall in love with her. This love will only bring pain for it will end up like the tragic Greek [[Mythology|myth]] of [[Orpheus]] and [[Eurydice]].
Two of the students, Klaus and Isaac, see a girl through the window. Not realizing she is a fellow student named Julius, who was raised to be a boy, things spin out of control and their lives are changed forever.

([[Japanese language|Japanese]]: ユリウス・レオンハルト・フォン・アーレンスマイヤ [[Hepburn romanization|Hepburn]]: ''Yuriusu Reonharuto fon Ārensumaiya'')
